title: I have figured out how to win every game
body:
The trick is very simple, it is to not die. I know that might sound very sarcastic, but its the truth.

 I am currently in the bronze division, and I watched some of my replays to help improve, and I noticed how many times we simply fight for absolutely NO REASON. Even after we fight and one of the teams have been aced, we simply go back to base and get more items. For what? We already killed them? Why do we have to prove we can do it (or worse NOT do it) again? 

I have watched some higher elo games and in some games they dont get first blood until 20 minutes in. 20 MINUTES IN A GAME FOR ONE KILL. After 20 minutes in a bronze game its 49 to 54 and the jungler hasn't even looked at a single drag. 

So I started paying attention and choosing battles when they are in my favor, and believe it or not I win more fights than i lose. Even when I am in a lane where I have been counter picked, as long as I don't feed the enemy and let them snowball, I AM WINNING MY LANE (of course cs is important too). 

So when you look top and notice the 0/9 darius on your team, you simply can't stop the 9/0 renekton coming for you. What makes this Darius think "man, next time i will get him for sure"? It is very hard to solo carry when others cant understand that not dying, is just as important as getting kills.

I've actually mentioned this to my friends and yeah it's improved my gameplay. A big "step to awakening" in league is  realizing THIS GAME IS NOT AN FPS WHERE YOU WIN BY RUSHING KILLS!!!!! So many people play this like it's COD or Halo and the first to hit 50 kills wins. You wanna play that way hit up FGM's that do it when they are out.

The 3 things I feel someone has to learn before they can truly start improving in league would be:
This is a team game and very few can 1 man army their way through it, cooperate.
Don't fight uselessly. Fight only when you think you can win it
PUSH AS HARD AS YOU POSSIBLY CAN WHEN YOU KILL ACE THE ENEMIES!

(Side note to that last one, also learn to watch death timers/mini map while pushing at any points in game. I haaaate when a bot lane thats under 100 hp gets all toxic cause they killed their laners and while at tower got ganked. Thats a thing thats taught via experience more than instruction tho)
I have used Call of Duty in a reference before, how you don't really need a team to win a match with it. But in League you do, goodluck in a 5v1 when the enemies scale, unlike in cod.
Oh, I thought the solution was "Join the Enemy team".

Most common causes of death, the bronze edition:

1. Stop overextending for CS and objectives. If you're alone, and you don't know where the enemy team is, _you're overextended_. Stay behind your active wards. Move with groups to establish more vision. When doing the latter, try to creep up behind your minion wave, as this also gives you vision.

2. Stop hard pushing without flash, unless 1) the enemy doesn't have flash or you know you win an all in, 2) you know where every member of the enemy team is, including the jungler.

3. Stop treating your tower as if it makes you immortal. If you know you're about to get three man dived, ping for help and back off until help arrives. Sometimes, this means straight up sacrificing your tower. That sucks, but it's better than giving up your tower _and_ your life.

4. Stop trying to contest objectives you can't actually contest. I'm looking at you, dragons. You're not going to successfully contest a dragon 3v5, so give it up and try to take an objective elsewhere. There's no point in three of you dying for a failed attempt on an ocean drake. (Caveat: if your jungler wants to suicide steal while you do this, that's acceptable.)
4a. Also stop trying to contest objectives when you're way behind. If it's 20-40, _you're not going to successfully fight for that air drake_. Stop it, give it up. Again, have your jungler attempt a solo steal while you trade the drake for pressure and objectives.

5. Stop trying to fight without the rest of your team. You're not going to win a 4v5. If your idiot teammate gets caught out and dies, don't chase after and try to avenge him in a blaze of scornful glory. It's not going to work. You're all going to die. Fall back and regroup until your teammate respawns.

6. Stop trying to save idiot teammates. Unless you're damned well sure you can save your mid laner, or unless they're _way_ more valuable than the rest of your team, don't sacrifice yourself to save them when they do something stupid. Odds are, both of you will just die.

7. Stop overstaying after securing an objective. If you've got the tower, the inhibitor, whatever, and you're all low on health/cooldowns or have a ton of gold to spend, back, reset, and prepare for the next push. _Don't stay_. You're only giving your opponent an opportunity to get back into the game by fighting you at your weakest.

8. Stop fighting when you've a ton of gold on you. _Even if you're ahead_, you're only giving your opponent the chance to get back into the game with a crucial shutdown. Don't do that. Stop it. Stop getting greedy. Cash out and come to the next fight even stronger.

9. Stop chasing deep into unknown territory, unless you're 100% sure where every member of the enemy team is. Odds are, that guy you're chasing is running toward his nearest teammate. If you don't know where you're going, _stop_ chasing. You're essentially overextending.

All right, that's all I can think of off-hand. Any more?

If you have a split pushing comp, make sure you keep up the pressure so the enemy team cannot deal with your split pusher. If the enemy team breaks off or you are going to, warn your split pusher... or that's the time to engage the enemy. More often than not they break off two to deal with the split push (particularly if it's {{champion:23}} or {{champion:24}} ). You now have a 4v3. Win that.

At least twice in the past week I've had games where I was split pushing ({{champion:83}} top), and i had top inhibitor tower and the inhib dead to rights. My team breaks off from pushing bot to go take dragon... enemy team is thus able to come and stop my push. I was like "WHY? Getting top inhib is more important than one cloud drake. The drake would still be there!"

As a Zed main it is awful when I am split pushing and my team engages in a 4v5. They continue to die, then /all "please report zed not being in team fight". Like its my fault for getting 2 towers :' )

Truth. Split pushing is a fine art. You need to keep the pressure on without dying to a sudden engage, yet you need to be able to engage when they break off. If you do it right, one of your groups is going to get at least one tower. Period.

I've had it where the enemy team sends the one fed person to come deal with the Yorick... and they die to me (I'm consistently underestimated for 1v1s). Meanwhile, my team wins the 4v4, and we get an ace. That's two inhibs. Recall, baron, and end it. Make them eat the super minion shit sandwich by pushing the last inhib. That game is yours in the next 3:30, it's just a matter of when and not throwing.

The concept of the game is very simple.
Kill the enemy nexus.
To kill the enemy nexus, you must destroy towers.
To make destroying towers easier, you need to open up an opportunity to destroy them.
Killing enemy champions opens up the opportunity, as they're the real reason the tower stays alive.  They too have a brain.

So to summarize:  killing enemy champions isn't for gold or glory, it's for opportunity.  It opens up windows of weakness on objectives.

When you dance outside the enemy nexus after they've been aced, you're really just wasting opportunity.  People have literally lost games because they could've attacked the nexus, but chose to dance outside the enemy fountain.

If everyone understood this, bronze and silver would be a hell of a lot harder for gold/plat to climb out of.  Hell, a lot of them wouldn't be able to anymore.

To edit in: it does go both ways.  Sometimes you're the one that is beat.  You can't open up that opportunity to take something, You can still prevent them from opportunities of their own.
You sure about that brain part? Cause I sometimes wonder.

But you have to take objectives sometime, or you loose anyway. 
It's not a deathmatch.

An assumption of play style often ends poorly for the one doing the assuming. I speak from personal experience. Assuming a Nasus who E-Max's first is going AP will ultimately end you itemizing poorly when he then goes for the traditional build after he has amassed enough farm. 

Personally I think E-max is fundamentally weaker playstyle that rewards a lazy play style of Nasus that will ultimately back fire. However putting 3 levels in E early vs ranged AA champions like Teemo, Vayne and Draven is often wise especially if you are higher elo and they know wtf they are doing. But you have to go for Q max after that 3rd point and start getting stacked b/c even if you out farmed they will out scale if you do not get the damage on your Q. 

Basically never assume anything. Darius is also one of those champs who always needs respected even if he did shitty in lane b/c he still has a passive AD bleed, true damage and hell of a lot of armor shred and can easily turn a team fight around. I hope this gives you some perspective. =D
